claim: Cell- and egg-based flu vaccines have the potential to develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness.
explanation: A forest plot titled “Subgroup Analysis of Relative Vaccine Effectiveness against Influenza among Participants between 50 and 64 Years of Age, According to Preexisting Conditions.” The plot shows point estimates and 95% confidence intervals for relative effectiveness (percentage) of a recombinant influenza vaccine compared with a standard-dose vaccine. Subgroups are defined by PCR-confirmed influenza, hospitalization for PCR-confirmed influenza, and hospitalization for community-acquired pneumonia, each stratified by conditions (cardiovascular disease, respiratory disease, cardiorespiratory disease, obesity, diabetes, any of the above conditions). does not support the claim: the figure only presents comparative vaccine effectiveness data and does not include any information about mutations arising during cell- or egg-based vaccine production or their impact on effectiveness.

detailed_analysis.image_description: A forest plot titled “Subgroup Analysis of Relative Vaccine Effectiveness against Influenza among Participants between 50 and 64 Years of Age, According to Preexisting Conditions.” The plot shows point estimates and 95% confidence intervals for relative effectiveness (percentage) of a recombinant influenza vaccine compared with a standard-dose vaccine. Subgroups are defined by PCR-confirmed influenza, hospitalization for PCR-confirmed influenza, and hospitalization for community-acquired pneumonia, each stratified by conditions (cardiovascular disease, respiratory disease, cardiorespiratory disease, obesity, diabetes, any of the above conditions).
